headline.print_headline: F.T.C. Said To Prepare For Lawsuit Vs. Google

docs.abstract: Federal Trade Commission is preparing to recommend that the federal government sue Google, raising the ante in its antitrust confrontation with the search giant; case centers around whether Google manipulates search results to favor its own products, making it harder for competitors and their products to appear prominently on results pages.

headline.main: Europe Presses Google to Change Privacy Policy
headline.print_headline:
European Privacy Regulators Warn
Google on Data-Gathering Policies

docs.abstract: European privacy regulators warn Google that it must clarify what consumer information it gathers and shares with advertisers, or risk fines or legal action; 27 European agencies, in letter to Google chief Larry Page, ask company to modify its global privacy policy for dozens of online services so users have a clearer understanding of how their personal data is being collected and can better control how it is shared.

headline.main: Shares Fall Sharply as Google Earnings Are Released Early
headline.print_headline: Google Shares Fall on Disappointing Earnings

docs.abstract: Google shares plummet by more than 9 percent after the company releases a disappointing earnings report, spurring Nasdaq to halt trading in its shares in the early afternoon; company reported third-quarter net income of $2.18 billion, down from $2.73 billion a year ago, reflecting a reduction in the price advertisers pay per click on ads.

headline.main: As Microsoft Shifts Its Privacy Rules, an Uproar Is Absent
headline.print_headline: Microsoft Expands Gathering and Use of Data From Web Products

docs.abstract: Microsoft institutes policy that gives company broad leeway over how it gathers and uses personal information from consumers of its free, Web-based products like e-mail, search and instant messaging; Microsoft's shift draws far less notice, and outrage, than similar changes at Google, illustrating widespread confusion surrounding Internet consumer privacy.

docs.snippet: The difference in reactions to broader gathering and use of users’ data at Google and at Microsoft illustrates the confusion around Internet consumer privacy....
docs.lead_paragraph: Microsoft instituted a policy that gives the company broad leeway over how it gathers and uses personal information from consumers of its free, Web-based products like e-mail, search and instant messaging. Microsoft’s policy is now much the same as those of Google, write Edward Wyatt and Nick Wingfield. Google’s expanded powers drew scathing criticism from privacy advocates, probing inquiries from regulators and broadside attacks from rivals, including Microsoft. Read more »
